sourceDesc.p:
Play details
The book of Sir Thomas More. Genre: History. Date first published: 1844. Authorial attribution is questionable. Date first performed: 1593-1601?
From the 1911 Malone Society text, The Book of Sir Thomas More, via Literature Online

editorialDecl.p: For Addition III, Base text from transcription of manuscript in The Book of Sir Thomas More, ed. W. W. Greg (1911), reprinted 1961 (Oxford: The Malone Society)
1990 Gabrieli and Melchiori Revels edition followed silently for restorations and deletions so as to ignore changes by Hand C and for speaker attributions

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Doll Francis de Bard. Cauveler Williamson Sherwin John Lincoln George Betts Justice Suresbie Lord Mayor Sheriff Moore Earl of Surrey Lifter (prisoner) Recorder Earl of Shrewsbury Sir Thomas Palmer Sir Roger Cholmeley apprentice Harry apprentice Robin apprentice Kit. Randall Erasmus Faulkner Morris All/Two or more characters speaking together Lady Mayor Inclination; the Vice Prologue Vanity Bishop of Rochester Daughter of Moore Catesbie Downes Warder 1 Lieutenant Gough 1.Sherriff 2.Sherriff Hangman Messenger Wit Another recorder Crofts Officer Officer 2 Clown Wife of Moore Player Servant Luggins Clerk Roper's wife Roper Warder 2 Warder 3 Woman Gentleman Porter Butler Brewer Porter Horse-Keeper Moore's daughter married to Roper Other citizen Another citizen Sergeant at Arms (in Additions) Servingman

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

div0.stage: Enter at one end Iohn Lincolne with together,at the other end enters ffraunces de a lustie woman,he haling her by the arme

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Whither wilt thou hale me?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Whither I please, thou art my prize and I plead purchase of thee

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Purchase of me? away ye Rascal, I am an honest plain Carpenters wife and though I have no beauty to like a husband yet whatsoever is mine scorns to stoop to a stranger: hand off then when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: go with me quietly, or I will compel thee.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Compel me ye dogs face? thou thinkst thou hast the Goldsmiths wife in hand, whom thou enticedest from her husband with all his plate, and when
thou turnedest her home to him again, madest him like an Ass) pay for his wifes board.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: so will I make thy husband too, if please me

div0.stage: Enter Caueler with a paire of dooues, Williamson the Carpenter and Sherwin following him.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: here he comes himself, tell him so if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Caue.
sp.l: follow me no further, I say thou shalt not have them.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I bought them in Cheapeside, and paid my money for them.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: He did Sir indeed, and you offer him wrong, both to take them from him, and not restore him his money neither.

sp.speaker: Caue.
sp.l: If he paid for them, let it suffice that I possess them, Beef and brews may serve such hinds, are Pigeon's meat for a coarse Carpenter?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: It is hard when Englishmens patience must be thus jetted on by strangers and they not dare to revenge their own wrongs.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Lincolne, let us beat them down, and bear no more of these abuses.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: we may not Betts, be patient and hear more.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.l: How now husband? what, one stranger take thy food from thee, and another thy wife? by our Lady flesh and blood I think can hardly brooke that.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: will this gear never be otherwise? must these wrongs be thus endured?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: let us step in, and help to revenge their injury.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: what art thou that talkest of revenge? my Lord Ambassador shall once more make your Mayor have a check, if he punish thee not for this saucy presumption

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord Mayor, on the Ambassadors complaint, sent me to Newgate one day, because against my will) I took the wall of a stranger. you may do anything, the Goldsmith's wife, and mine now must be at your commandment.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: The more patient fools are ye both to suffer it.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Suffer it? mend it thou or he if ye can or dare, I tell thee fellow, if she were the Mayor of London's wife, had I her once in my possession, I would keep her in spite of him that durst say nay.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I tell thee Lombard, these words should cost thy best cap, were I not curbed by duty and obedience. The Mayor of London's wife? o God, shall it be thus?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: why Bettes am not I as dear to my husband, as my Lord Mayors wife to him, and wilt he thou so neglectfully suffer his thine own shame? Hands off proud stranger or him that bought me, if men's milky hearts dare not strike a stranger, yet women will beat them down, ere they bear these abuses.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Mistress, I say you shall along with me.

Touch not Doll Williamson lest she lay thee along on Gods dear earth. And you Sir, that allow such coarse cates to Carpenters, whilst Pigeons which they pay for, must serve your dainty appetite: deliver them back to my husband again or I will call so many women to mine assistance, as we will not leave one inch under-run of thee. If our husbands must be bridled by law, and forced to bear your wrongs, their wives will be a little lawless, and soundly beat ye.

sp.speaker: Caue.
sp.l: Come away de Bard and let us go complain to my Lord Ambassador

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Aye, go, and send him among us, and we will give him his welcome too. I am ashamed that free born Englishmen, having beaten strangers within their own bon should thus be braved and abused by them at home.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: It is not our lack of courage in the cause, but the strict obedience that we are bound too: I am the Goldsmith whose wrongs you talked of, but how to redress yours or mine own, is a matter beyond all our abilities.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Not so, not so my good friends, I, though a mean man, a Broker by profession and named Iohn Lincolne have long time winked at these vild enormities with mighty impatience, and, as these two brethren here Betses by name) can witness with loss of mine own life would gladly remedy them

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: And he is in a good forwardness I tell ye, if all hit right.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: As how, I pre thee? tell it to Doll Williamson

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: you know the Spittle Sermons begin the next week, I have drawn a of our wrongs, and the strangers insolences.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: which he means the preachers shall there openly publish in the Pulpit

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: o but that they would, in faith it would tickle our strangers thoroughly

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Aye, and if you men durst not undertake it before God we women
an honest woman from her husband why it is intolerable

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: But how find ye the preachers affected to

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Master doctor standish
form it and doubts not but happy success will ensue our wrongs you shall perceive there is no hurt in the Bill, here is a copy of it, I pray ye, hear it.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: with all our hearts, for Gods sake read it

to you all the worshipful Lords and masters of this City, that will take compassion over the poor people your neighbours, and also of the great importable hurts, losses and hindrances, whereof proceedeth extreme poverty to all the Kings subjects, that inhabit within this City and suburbs of the same. For so it is that Aliens and strangers eat the bread from the fatherless children, and take the living from all the Artificers, and the intercourse from all Merchants whereby poverty is so much increased, that every man bewaileth the misery of other, for crafts men be brought to beggary, and Merchants to neediness. wherefore, the premises considered, the redress must be of the commons, knit and united to one part. And as the hurt and damage grieveth all men, so must all men see to their willing power for remedy, and not suffer the said Aliens in their wealth, and the natural born men of this region to come to confusion.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Before God, it is excellent, and I will maintain the suite to be honest.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: well, say it is read, what is your further meaning in the matter?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: what? marry list to me. no doubt but this will store us with friends enough, whose names we will closely keep in writing, and on May day next in the morning we will go forth a-Maying, but make it the worst May day for the strangers that ever they saw: how say ye? do ye subscribe, or are ye fainthearted revolters

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Hold thee George Bettes, there is my hand and my heart, by the Lord I will make a Captain among ye, and do somewhat to be talk of forever after.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: My masters, ere we part, let us friendly go and drink together, and swear true secrecy upon our lives.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: There spake an Angel, come, let us along then.

div0.stage: An Arras is drawne,and behinde it as in Sessions)sit the L.Maior,Iustice Suresbie and other Iustices, Sheriffe Moore and the other Sherife sitting by,Smart is the Plaintife,Lifter the prisoner at the barre.

sp.speaker: L.Mai.
sp.l: having dispatched our weightier businesses,
we may give ear to petty felonies,
Master Sheriff Moore, what is this fellow?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord, he stands indicted for a purse,
he hath been tried, the Jury is together.

sp.speaker: L.Mai.
sp.l: who sent him in?

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: that did I my Lord,
Had he had right, he had been hanged ere this,
the only captain of the cutpurse crewe.

sp.speaker: L.Mai.
sp.l: what is his name?

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: As his profession is, Lifter my Lord,
one that can lift a purse right cunningly.

sp.speaker: L.Mai.
sp.l: And is that he accuses him?

sp.speaker: Sure
sp.l: The same my Lord, whom, by your honours leave,
I must say somewhat too, because I find,
in some respects he is well worthy blame.

sp.speaker: L.Mai.
sp.l: Good Master Justice Suresbie speak your mind,
we are well pleased to give you audience.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: hear me Smart, thou art a foolish fellow,
If Lifter be convicted by the law,
As, I see not how the Jury can acquit him:
I will stand to it, thou art guilty of his death.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord, that is worth the hearing.

sp.speaker: L.Mai.
sp.l: Listen then good Master Moore.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: I tell thee plain, it is a shame for thee,
with such a sum to tempt necessity.
no less than ten pounds Sir, will serve your turn,
to carry in your purse about with ye,
to crake and brag in Taverns of your money.
I promise ye, a man that goes abroad,
with an intent of truth, meeting such a booty
may be provoked to that he never meant.
what makes so many pilferers and felons,
but such fond baits that foolish people lay:
to tempt the needy miserable wretch.
ten pounds, odd money, this is a pretty sum,
to bear about, which were more safe at home,
fore God it were well to fine ye as much more
to the relief of the prisoners,
to teach ye be your own.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Good my Lord, soothe a for once
only to try conclusions in this case

sp.speaker: l. Maior
sp.l: Content good Master Moore. we will rise awhile,
And till the Jury can return their verdict
walk in the garden: how say ye Justices?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: we like it well my Lord, we will follow ye.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Nay Plaintiff, go you too, And Officers,

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: stand you aside, and leave the prisoner
to me awhile: Lifter come hither.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: what is your worships pleasure?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Sirrah, you know that you are known to me
And I have often saved ye from this place
since first I came in Office: Thou seest beside,
that Justice Suresbie is thy heavy friend,
for all the blame that he pretends to Smart:
for tempting thee with such a sum of money.
I tell thee what, devise me but a means,
to pick or cut his purse, and on my credit
and as I am a christian and a man
I will procure thy pardon for that Jest.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: Master Shrieve, seek not my overthrow,
you know Sir, I have many heavy friends
and more indictments like to come upon me.
you are too deep for me to deal withal,
you are known to be one of the wisest men that is in England.
I pray ye Master Sheriff, go not about
to undermine my life

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Lifter I am true subject to my King,
thou much mistakest me and for thou shalt not think,
I mean by this to hurt thy life at all:
I will maintain the act when thou hast done it.
Thou knowest there are such matters in my hands,
as if I pleased to give them to the Jury:
I should not need this way to circumvent thee.
All that I aim at, is a merry jest:
perform it Lifter and expect my best.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: I thank your worship, God preserve your life.
But Master Justice Suresbie is gone in,
I know not how to come near where he is.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Let me alone for that, I will be thy setter,
I will send him hither to thee presently,
under the colour of thine own request,
of private matters to acquaint him with.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: If ye do so Sir, then let me alone
forty to one but then his purse is gone.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: well said, but see that thou diminish not
one penny of the money, but give it me,
It is the cunning act, that credits thee.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: I will, good Master Sheriff, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: I see the purpose of this Gentleman
is but to check the folly of the Justice,
for blaming others in a desperate case,
wherein himself may fall as soon as any
to save my life it is a good adventure:
Silence there ho: now doth the Justice enter.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Now Sirrah, now what is your will with me?
wilt thou discharge thy conscience like an honest man?
what sayst to me sirrah be brief be brief.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: As brief Sir as I can
If ye stand fair, I will be brief anon.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: speak out and mumble not, what sayst thou Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: Sir, I am charged as God shall be my comfort
with more than is true

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Sir Sir, ye are indeed, with more than is true,
for you are flatly charged with felony.
you are charged with more than truth and that is theft,
more than a true man should be charged withal
Thou art a varlet, that is no more than true,
Trifle not with me, do not, do not Sirrah,
confess but what thou knowest, I ask no more.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: There be Sir, there be, if it shall please your worship,

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: There be varlet what be there, tell me what there be?
Come off or on, there be, what be there, knave?

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: There be Sir divers very cunning fellows,
that while you stand and look them in the face:
will have your purse.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: thou art an honest knave.
tell me what are they? where they may be caught
Aye, those are they I look for.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: you talk of me Sir
Alas I am a puny: there is one indeed,
goes by my name he puts down all for purses
as familiar as thou wilt my knave
it is this I long to know.

sp.speaker: Lift
sp.l: And you shall have your longing ere ye go.
This fellow Sir, perhaps will meet ye thus,
Or thus, or thus, and in kind complement,
action
pretend acquaintance, somewhat doubtfully,
And these embraces serve.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Aye marry Lifter wherefore serve they?

sp.speaker: Lift
sp.l: Only to feel
whether you go full under sail or no,
Or that your lading be aboard your Bark.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: in plainer English Lifter if my purse be stored or no?

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: ye have it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Excellent, excellent.

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: Then Sir, you cannot but for manners sake,
walk on with him, for he will walk your way:
Alleadging either you have much forgot him,
or he mistakes you.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: But in this time has he my purse or no?

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: Not yet Sir, fie: no nor I have not yours.
But now we must forbear, my Lords return.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: A murrain on it: Lifter, we will more anon.
Aye, thou sayst true, there are shrewd knaves indeed
But let them gull me, wigeon me, rook me, fop me,
in faith in faith, they are too short for me.
knaves and fools meet when purses go,
wise men look to their purses well enough.
Lifter is it done?
done Master Shrieve, and there it is.
Then build upon my word, I will save thy life.

sp.speaker: Recor.
sp.l: Lifter stand to the bar,
the Jury have returned thee guilty, thou must die,
according to the custom, look to it Master Shrieve.

sp.speaker: l Maior.
sp.l: Then Gentlemen, as you are wont to do,
because as yet we have no burial place,
what charity your meaning is to bestow,
toward burial of the prisoners now condemned
let it be given, there is first for me.

sp.speaker: Recor.
sp.l: And there is for me.

sp.speaker: Another.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Body of me my purse is gone.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: gone Sir? what here? how can that be?

sp.speaker: l Maior.
sp.l: Against all reason, sitting on the bench?

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Lifter I talked with you, you have not lifted me? ha?

sp.speaker: Lift.
sp.l: Suspect ye me Sir? o what a world is this?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: But hear ye Master Suresbie, are ye sure
ye had a purse about ye?

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: Sure Master Shrieve, as sure as you are there,
and in it seven pounds odd money on my faith.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Seven pounds odd money? what were you so mad,
being a wise man, and a Magistrate
to trust your purse with such a liberal sum.
Seven pounds, odd money fore God it is a shame:
with such a sum to tempt necessity,
I promise ye, a man that goes abroad
with an intent of truth, meeting such a booty,
may be provoked to that he never thought.
what makes so many pilferers and felons,
but these fond baits that foolish people lay:
to tempt the needy miserable wretch
Should he be taken now that has your purse,
I would stand to it, you are guilty of his death,
for questionless, he would be cast by law.
it were a good deed to fine ye as much more
to the relief of the poor prisoners,
to teach ye lock your money up at home.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.l: well Master Moore you are a merry man,
I find ye Sir, I find ye well enough.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Nay, ye shall see Sir, trusting thus your money,
and Lifter here in trial for like case,
But that the poor man is a prisoner,
it would be now suspected that he had it.
Thus may ye see what mischief often comes:
by the fond carriage of such needless sums.

sp.speaker: l Maior.
sp.l: Believe me Master Suresbie, this is strange,
you being a man so settled in assurance,
will fall in that which you condemned in other.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: well Master Suresbie there is your purse again,
and all your money fear nothing of Moore
wisdom still the door.

div0.stage: Enter the Earles of Shrewesburie and Surrie Sir Thomas Palmer and Sir Roger Cholmeley

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: My Lord of Surrey, and Sir Thomas Palmer,
might I with patience tempt your grave advise.
I tell ye true, that in these dangerous times,
I do not like this frowning vulgar brow.
My searching eye did never entertain,
a more distracted countenance of grief
than I have late observed
in the displeased commons of the City.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: it is strange, that from his princely clemency,
so well a tempered mercy and a grace,
to all the Aliens in this fruitful land,
that this high crested insolence should spring,
from them that breathe from his majestic bounty,
that fattened with the traffic of our country:
already leap into his subjects face.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: yet Sherwin hindered to commence his suite
against the Bard by the Ambassador
by supplication made unto the King.
who having first enticed away his wife,
and got his plate, near worth four hundred pound,
to grieve some wronged Citizens, that found,
this vile disgrace oft cast into their teeth:
of late sues Sherwin, and arrested him
for money for the boarding of his wife.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: The more Knave Bard that using Sherwins goods,
doth ask him interest for the occupation:
I like not that my Lord of Shrewesburie.
he is ill bested, that lends a well paced horse,
unto a man that will not find him meat.

sp.speaker: Cholme.
sp.l: My Lord of Surrey will be pleasant still.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I being then employed by your honours
to stay the broil that fell about the same,
where by persuasion I enforced the wrongs,
and urged the grief of the displeased city:
He answered me and with a solemn oath
that if he had the Mayor of London's wife,
he would keep her in despite of any English

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: it is good Sir Thomas then for you and me,
your wife is dead, and I a Bachelor
If no man can possess his wife alone,
I am glad Sir Thomas Palmer I have none.

sp.speaker: Cholme.
sp.l: If he take my wife, he shall find her meat.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: And reason good Sir Roger Cholmeley) too.
If these hot frenchmen needlessly will have sport,
they should in kindness yet defray the charge.
it is hard when men possess our wives in quiet:
and yet leave us in to discharge their diet.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: My Lord, our Caters shall not use the markete,
for our provision, but some stranger LOMBARD now:
will take the victuals from him he hath bought.
A Carpenter, as I was late informed,
who having bought a pair of dooues in Cheap,
immediately a frenchman Lombard took them from him,
and beat the poor man for resisting him.
And when the fellow did complain his wrongs:
he was severely punished for his labour.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: But if the English blood be once but up,
as I perceive their hearts already full
I fear me much, before their spleens be cold,
some of these saucy Aliens for their pride,
will pay for it soundly, wheresoever it lights.
this tide of rage, that with the Eddie strives:
I fear me much will drown too many lives.

sp.speaker: Cholme.
sp.l: Now afore God, your honours, pardon me,
men of your place and greatness, are to blame,
I tell ye true my Lords, in that his Majesty
is not informed of this base abuse,
and daily wrongs are offered to his subjects
for if he were, I know his gracious wisdom,
would soon redress it.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Sirrah, what news?

sp.speaker: Cholme.
sp.l: None good I fear

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: My Lord, ill news, and worse I fear will follow
if speedily it be not looked unto.
The City is in an uproar and the Mayor,
is threatened if he come out of his house
a number poor artifi
feared what this would come unto.
this follows on the doctors publishing
the bill of wrongs in public at the Spittle.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: that doctor Beale may chance beshrew himself
for reading of the bill

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Let us go gather forces to the Mayor,
for quick suppressing this rebellious route.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Now I bethink myself of Master Moore,
one of the Sheriffs, a wise and learned Gentleman,
and in especial favour with the people.
He backed with other grave and sober men,
may by his gentle and persuasive speech
perhaps prevail more then we can with power.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Believe me, but your honour well advises.
Let us make haste, or I do greatly fear:
some to their graves this mornings work will bear.

div0.stage: Enter Lincolne,Betses,Williamson,Sherwin and other armed,doll in a shirt of Maile,a head piece, sword and Buckler,a crewe attending.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Peace there I say, hear Captain Lincolne speak,
Keep silence, till we know his mind at large.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, speak then brave Captain Lincolne.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Come gallant bloods, you, whose free souls do scorn
to bear the enforced wrongs of Aliens.
Add rage to resolution, fire the houses
of these audacious strangers. This is is it Martins
and yonder dwells Mewtas a wealthy Piccarde, at the green gate,

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: with many more outlandish fugitives.
Shall these enjoy more privilege than we
in our own country? let us then become their slaves.
Since justice keeps not them in greater awe
we will be ourselves rough ministers at law.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: fire the houses, fire the houses.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Aye, for we may as well make bonfires on May day, as at Midsummer, we will
alter the day in the Calendar, and set it down in flaming letters.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: Stay, that would much endanger the whole City
whereto I would not the least prejudice

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: no nor I neither, so may mine own house be burned for company, I will tell ye what, we will drag the strangers out into Moore fields, and there bombast them till they stink again.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Let some of us enter the strangers houses,
and if we find them there, then bring them forth.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: If ye bring them forth before ye find them, I will never allow of that.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Now Lads, how shall we labour in our safety?
I hear the Mayor hath gathered men in Arms
and that Sheriff Moore an hour ago received
some of the privy Council in at Ludgate,
force now must make our peace or else we fall
it will soon be known we are the principal

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: And what of that? if thou beest afraid husband, go home again and hide
thy head, for by the Lord I will have a little sport now I am at it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: let us stand upon our Guard, and if they come
receive them as they were our enemies.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: How now? have ye found any?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: Not one, they are fled.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Then fire the houses, that the Mayor being busy,
about the quenching of them, we may scape.
Burn down their kennels let us away,
lest that this prove to us an ill May day.

div0.stage: Enter three or foure Prentises of trades,with a paire of Cudgelles.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.l: Come, lay down the Cudgels. Ho Robin, you met us well at Bunhill, to have you with us a-maying this morning?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: faith Harrie, the head drawer at the Mitre by the great Conduit, called me up, and we went to breakfast into Saint Annes lane. But come, who begins? in good faith I am clean out of practise: when wast at Garrets school Harrie?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Not this great while, never since I brake his ushers head, when he played his scholars prize at the Star in Bread street, I use all to George Philpots at Dow gate, he is the best back sword man in England.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Bate me an Ace of that, quoth Bolton.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I will not bate ye a pin on it Sir, for, by this cudgel it is true.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: I will cudgel that opinion out of ye: did you break an ushers head Sir?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Aye marry did I Sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: I am very glad on it, you shall break mine too if ye can.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Sirrah, I pre thee what art thou?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: why, I am a Prentice as thou art, seest thou now: I will play with thee at blunt here in Cheapeside, and when thou hast done, if thou beest angry, I will fight with thee at in Moore fields I have a sword to serve my turn in a favour come Iulie, to serve
to persist in it, is present death. but if you yield yourselves, no doubt, what punishment you in simplicity have incurred, his highness in mercy will most graciously pardon.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: we yield, and desire his highness mercy.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: no doubt his majesty will grant it you
But you must yield to go to several prisons,
till that his highness will be further known.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Most willingly, whether you will have us.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Lord Mayor, let them be sent to several prisons,
and there in any case, be well entreated.
My Lord of Surrie, please you to take horse,
and ride to Cheap side, where the Aldermen,
are with their several companies in Arms.
will them to go unto their several wards,
both for the stay of further mutiny,
and for the apprehending of such persons:
as shall contend.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I go my noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: we will straight go tell his highness these good news.
withal Shrieve Moore) I will tell him, how your breath:
hath ransomed many a subject from sad death.

sp.speaker: l Maior.
sp.l: Lincolne and Sherwine, you shall both to Newgate,
the rest unto the Counters.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: go, guard them hence, a little breath well spent,
cheats expectation in his fairest event.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: well Sheriff Moore, thou haste done more with thy good words, than all they could with their weapons: give me thy hand, keep thy promise now for the Kings pardon, or by the Lord I will call thee a plain Cony catcher.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: farewell Shrieve Moore, and as we yield by thee
so make our peace, then thou dealest honestly.

sp.speaker: l Maior.
sp.l: Master Shrieve Moore, you have preserved the City,
from a most dangerous fierce commotion.
For if this limb of riot here in Saint Martins,
had joined with other branches of the city,
that did begin to kindle, it would have bred,
great rage, that rage, much murder would have fed.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: not Steel but eloquence hath wrought this good.
you have redeemed us from much threatened blood.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord, and brethren, what I here have spoke,
my countries love, and next, the Cities care:
enjoined me to, which since it thus prevails,
think, God hath made weak Moore his instrument,
to thwart seditions violent intent.
I think it were best my Lord, some two hours hence,
we meet at the Guild hall, and there determine,
that through every ward, the watch be clad
in Armour, but especially provide
that at the City gates, selected men,
substantial Citizens do ward tonight,
for fear of further mischief.

sp.speaker: l Maior.
sp.l: It shall be so.
but yond methinks my Lord of Shrewesburie.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: My Lord, his majesty sends loving thanks,
to you, your brethren, and his faithful subjects
your careful Citizens. But Master Moore, to you,
a rougher, yet as kind a salutation,
your name is yet too short, nay, you must kneel,
a Knights creation is this Knightly steel.
Rise up Sir Thomas Moore.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I thank his highness for thus honouring me.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: This is but first taste of his princely favour,
for it hath pleased his high majesty,
noting your wisdom and deserving merit,
to put this staff of honour in your hand,
for he hath chose you of his privy Council.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord, for to deny my Sovereigns bounty,
were to drop precious stones into the heaps
whence first they came, from whence they would never return,
to urge my imperfections in excuse,
were all as stale as custom. no my Lord,
my service is my Kings, good reason why:
since life or death hangs on our Sovereigns eye.

sp.speaker: l Maior.
sp.l: His majesty hath honoured much the city
in this his princely choice.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord and brethren,
though I depart for my love shall rest
I now must sleep in court, sound sleeps forbear,
the Chamberlain to state is public care.
yet in this rising of my private blood:
my studious thoughts shall tend the cities good.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: How now Croftes? what news?

sp.speaker: Croftes.
sp.l: My Lord, his highness sends express command,
that a record be entered of this riot,
And that the chief and capital offenders
be thereon straight arraigned, for himself intends
to sit in person on the rest tomorrow
at westminster.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Lord Mayor, you hear your charge.
Come good Sir Thomas Moore, to Court let us hie
you are the appeaser of this mutiny.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord farewell, new days begets new tides
Life whirls about fate, then to a grave it slides.

div0.stage: Enter M r Sheriffe, and meete a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Messenger, what news?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Is execution yet performed?

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Not yet, the Carts stand ready at the stayres,
and they shall presently away to Tibourne.

sp.speaker: Messe.
sp.l: Stay Master Shrieve, it is the Counsels pleasure,
for more example in so bad a case,
a Jibbet be erected in Cheapside,
hard by the Standard, whither you must bring
Lincolne and those that were the chief with him,
to suffer death, and that immediately.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: It shall be done Sir. Officers, be speedy
call for a Jibbet, see it be erected,
others make haste to Newgate, bid them bring,
the prisoners hither, for they here must die,
Away I say, and see no time be slacked.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: we go Sir.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: that is well said fellows, now you do your duty
sp.stage: ex.some seuerally,others set vp the Iibbit
sp.l: God for his pity help these troublous times
The streets stopped up with gazing multitudes,
command our armed Officers with Halberds,
make way for entrance of the prisoners.
Let proclamation once again be made,
that every householder, on pain of death
keep in his Prentices, and every man,
stand with a weapon ready at his door,
as he will answer to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I will see it done Sir.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.l: Bring them away to execution,
the writ is come above two hours since,
the City will be find for this neglect.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: there is such a press and multitude at Newgate,
they cannot bring the Carts unto the stayres
to bring take the prisoners in.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.l: Then let them come on foot,
we may not dally time with great command.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Some of the Bench Sir, think it very fit
that stay be made, and give it out abroad
the execution is deferred till morning,
And when the streets shall be a little cleared,
to chain them up, and suddenly dispatch it.

div0.stage: The Prisoners are brought in well guarded.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.l: Stay, in mean time methinks they come along.
See, they are coming, so, it is very well.
Bring Lincolne there the first unto the tree.

sp.speaker: CLO>
sp.l: Aye for I cry lag Sir

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: I knew the first Sir, did belong to me.
This the old proverb now complete doth make,
that Lincolne should be hanged for London's sake.
In Gods name, let us to work: fellow, dispatch,
I was the foremost man in this rebellion
and I the foremost that must die for it.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Bravely Iohn Lincolne let thy death express,
that as thou livedest a man, thou diedest no less.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Doll williamson thine eyes shall witness it.
Then to all you that come to view mine end,
I must confess, I had no ill intent,
but against such as wronged us over much.
And now I can perceive, it was not fit,
that private men should carve out their redress,
which way they list, no, learn it now by me
obedience is the best in each degree.
And asking mercy meekly of my King,
I patiently submit me to the law.
But God forgive them that were cause of it.
and as a Christian, truly from my heart:
I likewise crave they would forgive me too.
that others by example of the same
henceforth be warned to attempt the like
against any alien that repaireth hither
fare ye well all, the next time that we meet
I trust in heaven we shall each other greet.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: farewell Iohn Lincolne say all what they can:
thou livedest a good fellow, and diedest an honest man.

sp.speaker: CLO
sp.p: would I were so far on my Journey the first stretch is the worst methinks

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Bring williamson there forward.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Good Master Shrieve, I have an earnest suite,
and as you are a man deny it me not.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: woman, what is it? be it in my power,
thou shalt obtain it.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Let me die next Sir, that is all I crave,
you know not what a comfort you shall bring
to my poor heart to die before my husband.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Bring her to death, she shall have her desire.

sp.speaker: CLO
sp.p: Sir and I have a suite to you too what is it that as you have hanged lincolne first and will hang her next so that you will not hang me at all
nay you set ope the counter gates and you must hang the folly
well then so much for that

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Sir, your free bounty much contents my mind,
Commend me to that good Shrieve Master Moore,
and tell him had it not been for his persuasion,
Iohn Lincolne had not hung here as he does.
we would first have locked up in Leaden hall,
and there been burnt to ashes with the roof.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: woman, what Master Moore did, was a subjects duty,
and hath so pleased our gracious Lord the King,
that he is hence removed to higher place,
and made of Council to his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: well is he worthy of it by my troth,
an honest, wise, well spoken Gentleman,
yet would I praise his honesty much more,
if he had kept his word, and saved our lives,
but let that pass, men are but men, and so,
words are but words, and pays not what men owe.
Now husband, since perhaps the world may say,
that through my means thou comest thus to thy end:
here I begin this cup of death to thee,
because thou shalt be sure to taste no worse,
than I have taken, that must go before thee.
what though I be a woman, that is no matter,
I do owe God a death, and I must pay him.
Husband, give me thy hand, be not dismayed,
this char being charred, then all our debt is paid.
Only two little babes we leave behind us,
and all I can bequeath them at this time,
is but the love of some good honest friend:
to bring them up in charitable sort.
what masters, he goes upright that never halts,
and they may live to mend their parents faults.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: why well said wife, in faith thou cheerest my heart,
give me thy hand, let us kiss, and so let us part.

div0.stage: he kisses her on the ladder.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: The next kiss williamson, shall be in heaven.
Now cheerily Lads, George Bets, a hand with thee,
and thine too Rafe, and thine good honest Sherwin.
Now let me tell the women of this town,
no stranger yet brought doll to lying down.
so long as I an Englishman can see,
Nor french nor dutch shall get a kiss of me.
And when that I am dead, for me yet say,
I died in scorn to be a strangers prey.

sp.p: Room for the Earl of Surrey, room there room.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Save the man's life, if it be possible.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: It is too late my Lord, he is dead already.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I tell ye Master Sheriff, you are too forward,
to make such haste with men unto their death,
I think your pains will merit little thanks
since that his Highness is so merciful,
as not to spill the blood of any subject.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: My noble Lord, would we so much had known,
the Counsels warrant hastened our dispatch,
it had not else been done so suddenly:

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Sir Thomas Moore humbly upon his knee,
did beg the lives of all, since on his word
they did so gently yield. The King hath granted it,
and made him Lord high Chancellor of England,
according as he worthily deserves.
Since Lincolnes life cannot be had again,
then for the rest, from my dread Sovereigns lips,
I here pronounce free pardon for them all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: God save the King, God save the King,
my good Lord Chancellor and the Earl of Surrey.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: And doll desires it from her very heart,
Moores name may live for this right noble part.
And whensoever we talk of ill May day:
praise Moore

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: in hope his highness clemency and mercy,
which in the arms of mild and meek compassion
would rather clip you, as the loving Nurse
oft doth the wayward Infant, than to leave you,
to the sharp rod of Justice so to draw you,
to shun such lewd assemblies, as beget
unlawful riots and such traitorous acts,
that striking with the hand of private hate,
maim your dear country with a public wound.
o God, that mercy, whose majestic brow,
should be unwrinkled, and that awful justice,
which looketh through a veil of sufferance
upon the frailty of the multitude
should with the clamours of outrageous wrongs,
be stirred and wakened thus to punishment.
But your deserved death he doth forgive,
who gives you life, pray all he long may live

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: God save the King, God save the King,
my good Lord Chancellor and the Earl of Surrey.

div0.stage: A table beeing couered with a greene Carpet, a state Cushion on it, and the Pursse and Mace lying thereon Enter Sir Thomas Moore and his man Randall with him, attyred like him.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Come on Sir, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: yes my Lord, I stand but upon a few points, I shall have done presently,
Is it your honours pleasure that I should be grow proud now?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Aye, I must have thee proud, or else thou wilt never
be near allied to greatness: observe me Sir.
The learned Clarke Erasmus is arrived
within our English Court, this day I hear,
he feasteth with an English honoured Poet
the Earl of Surrey, and I know this night
the famous Clarke of Roterdame will visit
Sir Thomas Moore, therefore Sir, act my part,
there, take my place furnished with purse and Mace.
I will see if great Erasmus can distinguish
merit and outward ceremony: observe me Sirrah,
I will be thy glass, dress thy behaviour
according to my carriage, but beware
thou talk not overmuch, for it will betray thee.
who prates not oft, seems wise, his wit few scan,
whilst the tongue blabs tales of the imperfect man.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I conceive your Lordship, and have learned your shift so well, that I must needs be apprehensive

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: This Music tells us, that the Earl is come
with learned Erasmus Now my Lord Chancellor,
Act like a formal Player our grave part.

sp.speaker: Ran
sp.l: I pray ye my Lord, let me command ye to leave me, if I do it not in kew, let
your Lordship banish me from the wearing of a gold chain forever.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: They come now, set thy countenance, act thy part
with a firm boldness, and thou winnest my heart.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Now great Erasmus you approach the presence,
of a most learned worthy Gentleman.
This little I will holds not a truer friend
unto the Arts: nor doth his greatness add
a feigned flourish to his worthy merit.
he is great in study, that is the statists grace,
that gains more reverence then the outward place.

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.l: Report my Lord hath crossed the narrow Seas,
and to the several parts of Christendom
hath borne the fame of your Lord Chancellor.
I longed to see him, whom with loving thoughts
I in my study oft have visited.
Is yond Sir Thomas

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: It is Erasmus
Now do you view the most honourable Scholar,
the most religious Politician,
the worthiest Councellor that tends our state.
that Study is the general watch of England,
in it, the Princes safety, and the peace,
that shines upon our common weal, are forged.
upon the golden Anvil of his brain.
who cures the Realm, such care attends the great,
that mind and body must together sweat.

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.l: His Lordship hath some weighty business sure,
for see, as yet he takes no notice of us.
I think it were best I do my duty to him
in a short Latin speech.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: It will do well,
he is the best linguist that we have in England.

l.foreign: Cum tua virtus,amplissim doctissime que vir)

sp.l: methinks this strange and Ruffian-like disguise,
fits not the follower of a secretary.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.l: My Lord, I wear my hair upon a vow.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: But for no penance of your sins I fear.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: no, he is no hair cloth man, though he wear hair.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: ffaulkener, how long is it since you cut your locks?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.l: Three years my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: How long will it be before your vow expire?

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.l: As many years as since my hair was cut.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Sure, vows are holy things, if they be made
to good intent, and Sir, you shall not say,
you were compelled by me to break your vow.
But till the expiration of the same,
because I will not have ye walk the streets,
for every man to stand and wonder at,
I will commit ye prisoner unto Newgate.
Except mean time, your conscience give you leave,
to dispense with the long vow that you have made
Away with him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: A Cell most meet for such a votary.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.l: well Sir, and I may perhaps be bailed ere it be long, and yet wear my hair

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: And Master Sheriff of London,
here in his highness name we give you charge,
continual watch be kept through out the city,
for the suppressing of these mutinies.
And if hereafter any that belong,
either to my Lord of winchester or Elie,
do come into your City with a weapon,
or above two of either faction,
shall be seen walking in the streets together
or meet in Tavern or in Ordinary,
they be committed presently to prison.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: And cause to be proclaimed about the City,
that no man whatsoever, that belongs,
either to my Lord of winchester or Elie,
do walk without the livery of his Lord,
either in cloak or any other garment,
that notice may be taken of the offenders.

div0.stage: Enter M ar Morris. & ex. Sherif and the rest.

sp.speaker: Moris.
sp.l: God save your honour my Lord Chancellor.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: welcome Master Morris, what news Sir?

sp.speaker: Moris.
sp.l: I come most humbly to entreat your honour,
in the behalf of a poor man of mine.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: what, the votary, that will not cut his hair,
until the expiration of his vow?

sp.speaker: Moris.
sp.l: My lord, being sorry for his rude behaviour,
he hath cut his hair, and doth conform himself
to honest decency in his attire.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: where is the fellow? I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Moris.
sp.l: here my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: you mock me surely, this is not the man.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.l: yes indeed my Lord, I am he.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Thou art not sure.
the other was an ugly filthy knave,
thou, a good featured and well favoured man.
why see what monsters you will make yourselves,
by cherishing a loathsome excrement,
to abuse the goodly image of a man,
whom God did frame so excellent a creature.
well, be a peaceable and civil man,
I do discharge thee.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.l: I humbly thank your honour.

sp.speaker: Moris.
sp.l: And myself
shall rest most thankful for this gracious favour.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: will it please your honours now to keep your way:
I fear the Lords are hindered by our stay.

sp.speaker: Moris.
sp.l: See Sir what your Ruffian tricks come too,
you think the eye of wisdom does not see,
into the brain-sick follies of vain heads,
but with your swaggering, you can bear it away.

sp.speaker: Faulk.
sp.l: Sir, I confess I have been much misgoverned,
and led by idle spleens, which now I see,
are like themselves, mere sottish vanity.
when the Jail I better called to mind
the grave rebukes of my Lord Chancellor
and looked into myself with more respect
than my rash heat before would let me
I caused a Barber presently be sent for
and moved your worship then for me.
but when I fall into
cashier me

div0.stage: Enter S r Thomas Moore M r Roper and Seruing men setting stooles.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Come my good fellows, stir, be diligent,
Sloth is an idle fellow, leave him now,
the time requires your expeditious service.
Place me here stools, to set the Ladies on.
son Roper you have given order for the banquet.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I have my Lord, and everythin is ready.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: o welcome wife, give you direction,
how women should be placed, you know it best.
For my Lord Mayor, his brethren, and the rest,
Let me alone, men best can order men

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I warrant ye my Lord, all shall be well
there is one without that stays to speak with ye,
And bad me tell ye that he is a Player.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: A Player wife? one of ye bid him come in,

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Nay stir there fellows, fie, ye are too slow.
See that your lights be in a readiness,
the Banquet shall be here. Gods me Madam,
leave my Lady Mayoress? both of us from the board?
and my son Roper too? what may our guests think?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My Lord, they are risen, and sitting by the fire.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: why yet go you and keep them company,
It is not meet we should be absent both.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: welcome good friend, what is your will with me?

sp.speaker: Player.
sp.l: My Lord, my fellows and myself,
are come to tender ye our willing service,
so please you to command us.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: what, for a play, you mean?
whom do ye serve?

sp.speaker: Player.
sp.l: My Lord Cardinals grace.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord Cardinals players? now trust me, welcome.
you happen hither in a lucky time,
to pleasure me, and benefit yourselves.
The Mayor of London, and some Aldermen,
his Lady, and their wives, are my kind guests
this night at supper. Now, to have a play,
before the banquet, will be excellent,
how think you son Roper

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: it will do well my Lord,
and be right pleasing pastime to your guests.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I pre thee tell me, what plays have ye?

sp.speaker: Player.
sp.l: divers my Lord: the Cradle of Security,
hit nail on the head, impatient poverty,
the play of four Pees, diues and Lazarus,
Lusty Iuuentus, and the marriage of wit and wisdom.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: The marriage of wit and wisdom? that my Lads,
I will none but that, the theme is very good,
and may maintain a liberal argument.
to marry wit to wisdom, asks some cunning,
Many have wit, that may come short of wisdom.
we will see how Master Poet plays his part,
and whether wit or wisdom grace his art.
go, make him drink, and all his fellows too,
how many are ye?

sp.speaker: Player.
sp.l: four men and a boy Sir.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: But one boy? then I see,
there is but few women in the play.

sp.speaker: Player.
sp.l: Three my Lord: dame Science, Lady vanity,
and wisdom she herself

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: And one boy play them all? by our Lady, he is laden.
well my good fellow get ye straight together,
and make ye ready with what haste ye may.
Provide their supper against the play be done,
else shall we stay our guests here over long.
make haste I pray ye.

sp.speaker: Player.
sp.l: we will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: where are the waits? go, bid them play,
to spend the time awhile. How now Madam

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My Lord they are coming hither.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: they are welcome: wife, I will tell ye one thing,
our sport is somewhat mended, we shall have
a play tonight: the marriage of wit and wisdom,
And acted by my good Lord Cardinals players.
how like ye that wife?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My Lord, I like it well.
See, they are coming.

div0.stage: The waytes playes, Enters Lord Maior,so many Aldermen as may,the Lady Maioresse in Scarlet, with other Ladyes and Sir Thomas Moores daughters, Seruaunts carying lighted Torches by them.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Once again welcome, welcome my good Lord Mayor,
And brethren all for once I was your brother,
and so am still in heart. It is not state,
that can our love from London separate.
naught but pride.
But they that cast an eye still whence they came,
know how they rose, and how to use the same.

sp.speaker: L.Maior.
sp.l: My Lord, you set a gloss on London's fame,
and make it happy ever by your name.
Needs must we say, when we remember Moore
it was he that drove rebellion from our door.
with grave discretions mild and gentle breath,
shielding a many subjects lives from death.
o how our City is by you renowned,
And with your virtues our endeavours crowned.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: no more my good Lord Mayor: but thanks to all,
that on so short a summons, you would come
to visit him that holds your kindness dear.
Madam, you are not merry with my Lady Mayoress,
And these fair Ladies, pray ye seat them all,
And here my Lord, let me appoint your place
the rest to seat themselves: Nay, I will weary ye,
you will not long in haste to visit me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good Madam sit, in sooth you shall sit here.

sp.speaker: La.Mai.
sp.l: Good Madam pardon me, it may not be.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: in troth I will have it so, I will sit here by ye,
Good Ladies sit, more stools here ho.

sp.speaker: La.Mai.
sp.l: It is your favour Madam makes me thus,
presume above my merit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: when we come to you,
then shall you rule us, as we rule you here.
Now must I tell ye Madam, we have a play,
to welcome ye withal: how good soever,
that know not I, my Lord will have it so.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: wife, hope the best, I am sure they will do their best,
they that would better, comes not at their feast.
My good Lord Cardinals players, I thank them for it,
play us a play, to lengthen out your welcome,
my good Lord Mayor, and all my other friends.
They say it is the marriage of wit and wisdom,
A theme of some import, however it prove:
but if art fail, we will inch it out with love.
what, are they ready?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Lord, one of the Players craves to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: with me? where is he?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: How now? what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: we would desire your honour but to stay a little, one of my fellows is but run to Oagles, for a long beard for young wit, and he will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: A long beard for young wit? why man, he may be with out a beard till he come to marriage, for wit goes not all by the hair: when comes wit in?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: in the second Scene, next to the Prologue my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: why play on till that Scene come, and by that time wits beard will be grown, or else the fellow returned with it. And what part playest thou?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: Inclination the vice my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Gramercies, now I may take the vice if I list: and wherefore hast thou that bridle in thy hand?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: I must be bridled anon my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: If thou beest not saddled too, it makes no matter, for then wits inclination may gallop so fast, that he will outstrip wisdom, and fall to folly.

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: Indeed so he does to Lady vanity: but we have no folly in our play.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Then there is no wit in it, I will be sworn: folly waits on wit, as the shadow on the body, and where wit is ripest, there folly still is readiest. But begin I pre thee, we will rather allow a beardless wit, than wit all beard to have no brain.

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: Nay, he has his apparel on too my Lord, and therefore he is the readier to enter.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Then good Inclination begin at a venture.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord Mayor: wit lacks a beard, or else they would begin,
I would lend him mine, but that it is too thin.
Silence, they come.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Now for as much as in these latter days,
throughout the whole world in every land;
vice doth increase and virtue decays,
Iniquity having the upper hand.
we therefore intend good gentle Audience,
a pretty short Interlude to play at this present,
desiring your leave and quiet silence,
to show the same as is meet and expedient.
It is called the marriage of wit and wisdom,
A matter right pithy and pleasing to hear,
whereof in brief we will show the whole sum
But I must begone, for wit doth appear.

div0.stage: Enter Witt ruffling, and Inclination the vice.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: in an arbour green, a sleep where as I lay,
The birds sang sweetly in the midst of the day,
I dreamed fast of mirth and play,
in youth is pleasure, in youth is pleasure.
Methought I walked still to and fro,
And from her company I could not go,
But when I waked, it was not so,
in youth is pleasure, in youth is pleasure.
therefore my heart is surely plight,
Of her alone to have a sight,
which is my joy and hearts delight,
in youth is pleasure, in youth is pleasure.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Mark ye my Lord, this is wit without a beard, what will he be, by that time he comes to the commodity of a beard?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: o Sir, the ground is the better on which she doth go.
For she will make better cheer with a little she can get:
then many a one can with a great banquet of meat.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: And is her name wisdom

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: Aye Sir, a wife most fit,
for you my good master, my dainty sweet Wit

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: to be in her company, my heart it is set.
therefore I pre thee to let us begone:
for unto wisdom Wit hath Inclination.

sp.speaker: Incli
sp.l: o Sir, she will come herself even anon.
For I told her before where we would stand
And then she said she would beck us with her hand.
Back with those boys, and saucy great knaves,
what, stand ye here so big in your braves?
my dagger about your coxcombs shall walk,
if I may but so much as hear ye chat or talk.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: But will she take pains to come for us hither?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: I warrant ye, therefore you must be familiar with her.
when she cometh in place,
you must her embrace, somewhat handsomely,
lest she think it danger,
because you are a stranger, to come in your company.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: I warrant thee Inclination, I will be busy,
o how wit longs to be in wisdom's company.

div0.stage: Enter Lady Vanitie singing.and beckning with her hand.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Come hither, come hither, come hither come:
Such cheer as I have, thou shalt have some.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: This is Lady Vanity I will hold my life:
beware good wit you take not her to wife.

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: what, unknown honesty, a word in your ear,
you shall not be gone as yet I swear.
here is none but your friends, you need not to fray,
this young Gentleman loves ye, therefore you must stay.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: I trust in me she will think no danger,
for I love well the company of fair women:
And though to you I am a stranger,
yet Wit may pleasure you now and then.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: who you? nay you are such a holy man,
that to touch one you dare not be bold:
I think you would not kiss a young woman,
if one would give ye twenty pound in gold.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: yes in good sadness Lady, that I would,
I could find in my heart to kiss you in your smock.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: My back is broad enough to bear that mock.
For it hath been told me many a time:
that you would be seen in no such company as mine.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Not Wit in the company of Lady Wisdom
o Jove for what do I hither come?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: Sir, she did this nothing else but to prove,
whether a little thing would you move,
to be angry and fret:
what and if one said so,
let such trifling matters go,
and with a kind kiss come out of her debt.
Is Luggins come yet with the beard?

sp.speaker: Player.
sp.l: no faith, he is not come, alas, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: forsooth we can go no further, till our fellow Luggins comes, for he plays good Council, and now he should enter, to admonish Wit that this is Lady Vanity and not Lady Wisdom

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Nay, if it be no more but so, ye shall not tarry at a stand for that, we will not have our play marred for lack of a little good Council: till your fellow come I will give him the best council that I can, pardon me my Lord Mayor, I love to be merry

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: o wit, thou art now on the bow hand,
And blindly in thine own opinion dost stand.
I tell thee, this naughty lewd Inclination,
Does lead thee amiss in a very strange fashion.
This is not Wisdom but Lady Vanity
therefore list to good council, and be ruled by me.

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: in troth my Lord, it is as right to Lugginses part, as can be, speak Wit.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Nay, we will not have our audience disappointed, if I can help it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Art thou good Council, and wilt tell me so?
wouldst thou have Wit from Lady Wisdom to go?
Thou art some deceiver, I tell thee verily,
in saying that this is Lady Vanity

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Wit judge not things by the outward show,
the eye oft mistakes, right well you do know.
Good council assures thee upon his honesty,
that this is not Wisdom but Lady Vanity

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: o my Lord, he is come, now we shall go forward.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Art thou come? well fellow, I have helped to save thine honesty a little, Now, if thou canst give wit any better council than I have done, spare not there I leave him to thy mercy.
But by this time, I am sure our banquet is ready,
My Lord, and Ladies, we will taste that first,
And then they shall begin the play again,
which through the fellows absence, and by me,
in stead of helping, hath been hindered.
Prepare against we come: Lights there I say,
thus fools oft times do help to mar the play.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: fie fellow Luggins, you serve us handsomely, do ye not think ye.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: why, Oagle was not within, and his wife would not let me have the beard, and by my troth I ran so fast that I sweat again.

sp.speaker: Incli.
sp.l: do ye hear fellows? would not my Lord make a rare player? o, he would uphold a company beyond all ho, better than Mason among the Kings players:
did ye mark how extemporarily he fell to the matter, and spake Lugginses part, almost as it is in the very book set down.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Peace, do ye know what ye say? my Lord a player? let us not meddle with any such matters: yet I may be a little proud, that my Lord hath answered me in my part, but come, let us go and be ready to begin the play again.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Aye, that is the best, for now we lack nothing.

div0.stage: Enter to the players w t h a reward
Enter the Earles of Shrewesburie,Surrey Bishop of Rochester and other Lordes,seuerally, dooing curtesie to eche other, Clark of the Councell waiting bareheaded.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Good morrow to my Lord of Shrewesburie.

sp.speaker: Shrew
sp.l: The like unto the honoured Earl of Surrey.
yond comes my Lord of Rochester

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: Good morrow my good Lords

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Clarke of the Council, what time is it of day?

sp.speaker: Clarke
sp.l: Past eight of clock my Lord.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: I wonder that my good Lord Chancellor,
doth stay so long, considering there is matters
of high importance to be scanned upon.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Clarke of the Council, certify his Lordship
the Lords expect him here.

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: It shall not need.
yond comes his Lordship.

div0.stage: Enter S r Thomas Moore with Pursse and Mace borne before him.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Good morrow to this fair assembly.
Come my good Lords, let us sit. o serious square,
upon this little board is daily scant
the health and preservation of the land.
we the Physicians that effect this good,
now, by choice diet, anon, by letting blood.
our toil and careful watching, brings the King
in league with slumbers, to which, peace doth sing.
Avoid the room there.
what business Lords today?

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: This my good Lord.
About the entertainment of the Emperor,
against the perfidious french into our pay.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: My Lords, as it is the custom in this place,
the youngest should speak first, so, if I chance,
in this case to speak youngly, pardon me.
I will agree, france now hath her full strength
as having new recovered the pale blood
which war sluiced forth, and I consent to this,
that the conjunction of our English forces
with arms of Germanie may sooner bring
this prize of conquest in. But then my Lords,
As in the moral hunting twixt the Lion,
and other beasts force joined
frighted the weaker sharers from their parts.
so if the Empires Sovereign chance to put,
his plea of partnership into wars Court,
Swords should decide the difference, and our blood:
in private tears lament his entertainment.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: to doubt the worst is still the wise man's shield,
that arms him safely, but the world knows this,
the Emperor is a man of royal faith.
His love unto our Sovereign, brings him down,
from his imperial seat, to march in pay
under our English flag, and wear the cross,
like some high order on his manly breast.
Thus serving, he is not Master of himself,
but like a Colonel, commanding other,
is by the General over awed himself.

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: yet my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Let me conclude my speech.
As subjects share no portion in the conquest
of their true Sovereign other than the merit,
that from the Sovereign guerdons the true subject:
so the good Emperor in a friendly league
of amity with England, will not soil
his honour with the theft of English spoil.

sp.speaker: Moore
sp.l: There is no question, but this entertainment:
will be most honourable, most commodious.
I have oft heard good Captains wish to have
rich Soldiers to attend them, such as would fight
both for their lives and livings. Such a one,
is the good Emperor: I would to God,
we had ten thousand of such able men,
ha, then there would appear, no Court, no City
but where the wars were: they would pay themselves.
Then to prevent in french wars, Englands loss:
let Germaine flags wave with our English cross.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: My Lords, his Majesty hath sent by me
these Articles enclosed, first to be viewed,
and then to be subscribed to: I tender them,
in that due reverence which befits this place.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Subscribe these Articles? stay, let us pause,
our conscience first shall parley with our laws.
My Lord of Rochester view you the paper.

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: Subscribe to these? now good Sir Thomas Palmer,
beseech the King that he will pardon me.
My heart will check my hand whilst I do write,
subscribing so, I were an hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: do you refuse it then my Lord?

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: I do Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then here I summon you forthwith to appear,
before his majesty, to answer there
this capital contempt.

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: I rise, and part,
in lieu of this, to tender him my heart.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: will it please your honour to subscribe my Lord?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Sir, tell his highness, I entreat
some time for to bethink me of this task.
in the mean while, I do resign mine office,
into my Sovereigns hands.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then my Lord,
hear the prepared order from the King.
on your refusal, you shall straight depart
unto your house at Chelsey till you know
our Sovereigns further pleasure.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Most willingly, I go.
My Lords, if you will visit me at Chelsey
we will go a-fishing, and with a cunning net,
not like weak film, we will catch none but the great.
farewell my noble Lords: why this is right,
good morrow to the Sun, to state good night.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: will you subscribe my Lords?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Instantly good Sir Thomas,
we will bring the writing unto our Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: My Lord of Rochester
you must with me, to answer this contempt.

sp.speaker: Roches.
sp.l: This is the worst,
who is freed from life, is from all care exempt.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: now let us to our Sovereign.
it is strange that my lord Chancellor should refuse
the duty that the law of God bequeaths
unto the King.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Come, let us in, no doubt,
his mind will alter, and the Bishops too,
Error in learned heads hath much to do.

div0.stage: Enter the Lady Moore,her two daughters,and M r Roper,as walking

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Madam, what ails ye for to look so sad.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Troth son, I know not what, I am not sick,
and yet I am not well: I would be merry
but somewhat lies so heavy on my heart:
I cannot choose but sigh. You are a Scholar,
I pray ye tell me, may one credit dreams?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: why ask you that, dear Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Because tonight, I had the strangest dream,
that ere my sleep was troubled with.
Methought it was night,
And that the King and Queen went on the Themes,
in Barges to hear music: My Lord and I
were in a little boat methought, Lord, Lord,
what strange things live in slumbers? And being near,
we grappled to the Barge that bare the King.
But after many pleasing voices spent,
in that still moving music house: methought,
the violence of the stream did sever us
quite from the golden fleet, and hurried us,
unto the bridge, which with unused horror,
we entered at full tide, thence some flight shoot,
being carried by the waves: our boat stood still
just opposite the Tower, and there it turned,
and turned about, as when a whirl poole sucks
the circled waters: methought that we both cried,
till that we sunk, where arm in arm we died.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: give no respect, dear Madam to fond dreams,
they are but 'slight illusions of the blood.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Tell me not all are so, for often dreams,
are true diviners, either of good or ill.
I cannot be in quiet, till I hear,
how my Lord fares.
Nor I. Come hither wife
I will not fright thy mother, to interpret
the nature of a dream: but trust me sweet,
this night I have been troubled with thy father:
beyond all thought.

sp.speaker: Ro. wife.
sp.l: Truly and so have I.
Methought I saw him here in Chelsey Church,
standing upon the Rood loft, now defaced.
And whilst he kneeled and prayed before the image,
it fell with him into the upper quire,
where my poor father lay all stained in blood.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: our dreams all meet in one conclusion
fatal, I fear.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: what is that you talk? I pray ye let me know it.

sp.speaker: Ro. wife
sp.l: Nothing good mother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: This is your fashion still, I must know nothing.
Call Master Catesbie, he shall straight to Court,
and see how my Lord does: I shall not rest,
until my heart leave panting on his breast.

div0.stage: Enter S r Thomas Moore merily,Seruaunts attending.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: See where my father comes, joyful and merry.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: As seamen, having past a troubled storm,
dance on the pleasant shore: so I, o I could speak
now like a Poet. Now afore God, I am passing light,
wife, give me kind welcome, thou wast wont to blame
my kissing, when my beard, was in the stubble,
But, I have been trimmed of late, I have had,
a smooth Court shaving, in good faith I have,
God bless ye: son Roper, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: your Honour is welcome home.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Honour? ha ha: And how dost wife?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: He bears himself most strangely.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: will your Lordship in?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Lordship? no wife, that is gone,
the ground was 'slight that we did lean upon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Lord that your Honour never will leave these Jests,
in faith it ill becomes ye.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: o good wife.
Honour and Jests are both together fled,
The merriest Councellor of England is dead.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: who is that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Still Lord? the Lord Chancellor wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: that is you.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Certain, but I have changed my life.
Am I not leaner than I was before,
the fat is gone: my title is only Moore.
Contented with one style, I will live at rest,
they that have many names, are not still best.
I have resigned mine office: countest me not wise?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: o God.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Come, breed not female children in your eyes.
the King will have it so.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: what is the offence?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Tush let that pass, we will talk of that anon.
The King seems a Physician to my fate,
His princely mind, would train me back to state.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Then be his patient my most honoured father.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: o son Roper
Vbi turpis est medicina,sanari piget.
no wife, be merry, and be merry all,
you smiled at rising, weep not at my fall.
let us in, and here joy like to private friends,
since days of pleasure have repentant ends.
The light of greatness is with triumph borne:
It sets at midday oft, with public scorn.

div0.stage: Enter the Bishop of Rochester,Surrey,Shrewsburie Lieutenant of the Tower,and warders with weapons.

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: Your kind persuasions, honourable Lords,
I can but thank ye for, but in this breast
there lives a soul, that aims at higher things,
than temporary pleasing earthly Kings.
God bless his Highness, even with all my heart,
we shall meet one day, though that now we part.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: we not misdoubt your wisdom can discern,
what best befits: it: yet in love and zeal;
we could entreat, it might be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: no doubt your fatherhood will by yourself,
consider better of this present case,
and grow as great in favour as before.

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: For that, as pleaseth God, in my restraint
from worldly causes, I shall better see
into myself, then at proud liberty.
The Tower and I will privately confer,
of things, wherein at freedom, I may err.
But I am troublesome unto your Honours;
and hold ye longer than becomes my duty.
Master Lieutenant, I am now your charge
And though you keep my body, yet my love,
waits on my King and you, while fisher lives.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: farewell my Lord of Rochester we will pray
for your release, and labour it as we may.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Thereof assure yourself, so do we leave ye,
And to your happy private thoughts bequeath ye.

sp.speaker: Rochest.
sp.l: Now Master Lieutenant, on, in Gods name go,
And with as glad a mind go I with you:
As ever truant bad the school adieu.

div0.stage: Enter S r Thomas Moore,his Lady,daughters,M r Roper Gentlemen and Seruaunts,as in his house at Chelsey.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: God morrow good son Roper, sit good Madam,
upon an humble seat, the time so craves,
rest your good heart on earth, the roof of graves.
you see the floor of greatness is uneven,
the Cricket and high throne alike near heaven.
Now daughters, you that like to branches spread,
and give best shadow to a private house:
Be comforted my Girls, your hopes stand fair,
virtue breeds gentry, she makes the best heir.

sp.speaker: both daugh.
sp.l: God morrow to your honour.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Nay, good night rather,
your honour is crest fallen with your happy father.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: o what formality, what square observance:
lives in a little room, here, public care,
gags not the eyes of slumber: here, fierce riot,
ruffles not proudly in a coat of trust,
whilst like a Pawn at Chess, he keeps in rank
with Kings and mighty fellows, yet indeed
those men that stand on tip toe, smile to see
him pawn his fortunes

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: True son
Nor does the wanton tongue here screw itself
into the ear, that like a vise, drinks up
the iron instrument.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: we are here at peace.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Then peace good wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For keeping still in compass, a strange point
in times new navigation, we have sailed
beyond our course.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: have done.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: we are exiled the Court.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Still thou harpest on that,
it is sin for to deserve that banishment,
but he that never knew Court courts sweet content.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: o but dear husband.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I will not hear thee wife,
The winding labyrinth of thy strange discourse,
will never have end. Sit still, and, my good wife,
entreat thy tongue be still: or credit me,
thou shalt not understand a word we speak
we will talk in Latin.
Humida vallis raros patitur fulminis ictus.
More rest enjoys the subject meanly bred,
than he that bears the Kingdom in his head.
Great men are still Musicians, else the world lies,
they learn low notes strains after the notes that rise.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Good Sir, be still yourself, and but remember,
How in this general Court of short lived pleasure
the world, creation is the ample food,
that is digested in the maw of time.
If man himself be subject to such ruin,
How shall his garment then, or the loose points,
that tie respect unto his awful place:
avoid destruction? Most honoured father in law,
the blood you have bequeathed these several hearts
to nourish your posterity, stands firm
As as with joy you led us first to rise
so with like hearts we will lock preferments eyes.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Close them not then with tears, for that ostent,
gives a wet signal of your discontent.
If you will share my fortunes, comfort then.
an hundred smiles for one sigh: what, we are men.
Resign wet wet passion to these weaker eyes,
which proves their sex, but grants never more wise.
let us now survey our state: here sits my wife,
and dear esteemed issue, yonder stand
my loving Servants, now the difference
twixt those and these. Now you shall hear me speak,
like Moore in melancholy. I conceive, that Nature
hath sundry metals, out of which she frames
us mortals, each in valuation
out prizing other. Of the finest stuff,
the finest features come, the rest of earth,
receive base fortune even before their birth.
Hence slaves have their creation and I think,
Nature provides content for the base mind,
under the whip, the burden and the toil,
their low wrought bodies drudge in patience.
As for the Prince, in all his sweet gorged maw,
and his rank flesh that sinfully renews
the noons excess in the nights dangerous surfeits,
what means or misery from our birth doth flow,
Nature entitles to us, that we owe.
But we being subject to the rack of hate,
falling from happy life to bondage state
having seen better days, now know the lack
of glory, that once reared each high fed back.
But that in your age did never view better,
challenge not fortune for your thriftless debtor.

sp.speaker: Catesbie.
sp.l: Sir, we have seen far better days, than these.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I was the patron of those days, and know,
those were but painted days, only for show,
then grieve not you to fall with him that gave them.

l.foreign: Pro hris generosis seruis gloriosum mori.

sp.l: dear Gough thou art my learned Secretary,
you Master Catesbie Steward of my house,
the rest like you) have had fair time to grow
in Sun shine of my fortunes. But I must tell ye,
Corruption is fled hence with each man's office.
Bribes that make open traffic twixt the soul,
and netherland of Hell, deliver up
their guilty homage to their second Lords
then living thus untainted, you are well
Truth is no Pilot for the land of hell
my Lord, there are new lighted at the gate,
the Earls of Surrie of Shrewesburie,
and they expect you in the inner Court.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Entreat their Lordships come into the hall.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: o God, what news with them?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: why how now wife?
They are but come to visit their old friend.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: o God, I fear, I fear.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: what shouldest thou fear fond woman?
Iustum si fractus illabatur orbis inpauidum ferient ruin.
here let me live estranged from great men's looks,
they are like golden flies on leaden hooks.

div0.stage: Enter the Earles,Downes with his Mace,and attendants.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Good morrow good Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Good day good Madam.
kind salutations.

sp.speaker: Moore
sp.l: welcome my good Lords.
