what ails your Lordships look so melancholy?
o I know you live in Court, and the Court diet,
is only friend to physic.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: o Sir Thomas,
our words are now the Kings, and our sad looks,
the interest of your love. we are sent to you,
from our mild Sovereign, once more to demand,
If you will subscribe unto those Articles,
he sent ye the other day, be well advised,
For on mine honour Lord, grave doctor fisher
Bishop of Rochester at the selfsame instant,
attached with you, is sent unto the Tower,
for the like obstinacy, his Majesty,
hath only sent you prisoner to your house.
But if you now refuse for to subscribe,
a stricter course will follow.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: o dear husband.

sp.speaker: both daugh.
sp.l: dear father.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: See my Lords,
this partner, and these subjects to my flesh:
prove rebels to my conscience: But my good Lords
if I refuse, must I unto the Tower?

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: you must my Lord, here is an officer,
ready for to arrest you of high treason.

sp.speaker: Lady and daugh.
sp.l: o God, o God.

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.l: Be patient good Madam.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I Downes is it thou? I once did save thy life,
when else by cruel riotous assault
thou hadst been torn in pieces: thou art reserved,
to be my Summoner to yond spiritual Court.
give me thy hand good fellow, smooth thy face,
the diet that thou drinkest, is spiced with mace,
and I could never abide it, it will not digest,
it will lie too heavy man, on my weak breast.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Be brief my Lord, for we are limited
unto an hour.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: unto an hour? it is well,
the bell earths thunder) soon shall toll my knell.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: dear loving husband, if you respect not me,
yet think upon your daughters.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: wife, stand up, I have bethought me,
and I will now satisfy the Kings good pleasure

sp.speaker: both daugh.
sp.l: o happy alteration.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: Come then, subscribe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I am right glad of this your fair conversion.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: o pardon me,
I will subscribe to go unto the Tower,
with all submissive willingness, and thereto add
my bones to strengthen the foundation
of Iulius Cæsars palace. Now my Lord,
I will satisfy the King, even with my blood,
Nor will I wrong your patience: friend, do thine office.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Sir Thomas Moore, Lord Chancellor of England, I arrest you in
the Kings name of high treason.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Gramercies, friend, and let us
to a great prison, to discharge the strife,
commenced betwixt conscience and my frailer life
Moore now must march. Chelsey adieu, adieu,
strange farewell, thou shalt never more see Moore true,
for I shall never see thee more: Servants farewell,
wife mar not thine indifferent face, be wise,
Moores widd husband, he must make thee rise.
Daughters what is here what is here?
Mine eye had almost parted with a tear
dear son, possess my virtue, that I never gave,
grave Moore thus lightly walks to a quick grave.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Cur leues loquuntur ingentes stupent.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: you that way in mind you my course in prayer:
by water I to prison, to heaven through air.

div0.stage: Enter the warders of the Tower with Halbards.

sp.speaker: 1.ward.
sp.l: Ho, make a guard there.
Master Lieutenant gives a straight command,
the people be avoided from the bridge.
From whence is he committed, who can tell?
From durham house I hear.
The Guard were waiting there an hour ago.
If he stay long, he will not get near the wharf,
there is such a crowd of Boats upon the Themes.
well, be it spoken with out offence to any,
A wiser, or more virtuous Gentleman
was never bred in England.
I think the poor will bury him in tears.
I never heard a man since I was born,
so generally bewailed of everyone.
what means this woman? whither dost thou press?
This woman will be trod to death anon.
what makest thou here?

sp.speaker: wo.
sp.l: to speak with that good man Sir Thomas Moore.
to speak with him? he is not Lord Chancellor.

sp.speaker: wo.
sp.l: The more is the pity Sir, if it pleased God.
therefore if thou hast a petition to deliver,
thou mayst keep it now, for anything I know.

sp.speaker: wo.
sp.l: I am a poor woman, and have had God knows,
a suite this two year in the Chancery,
And he hath all the evidence I have,
which should I lose, I am utterly undone.
faith, and I fear thou wilt hardly come by them now,
I am sorry for thee even with all my heart.

div0.stage: Enter the Lords with Sir Thomas Moore,and attendants,and enter Lieutenant and Gentleman Porter.

sp.l: woman stand back, you must avoid this place,
the Lords must pass this way into the Tower.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I thank your Lordships for your pains thus far,
to my strong house.

sp.speaker: wo.
sp.l: Now good Sir Thomas Moore, for Christ's dear sake,
deliver me my writings back again,
that do concern my title.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: what, my old client, are thou got hither too?
Poor silly wretch, I must confess indeed,
I had such writings as concern thee near,
But the King has taken the matter into his own hand,
he has all I had, then woman sue to him,
I cannot help thee, thou must bear with me.

sp.speaker: wo.
sp.l: Ah gentle heart, my soul for thee is sad,
farewell the best friend that the poor ever had.

sp.speaker: Gent. Por.
sp.l: Before you enter through the Tower gate,
your upper garment Sir belongs to me.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Sir you shall have it, there it is.

sp.speaker: Gent. Por.
sp.l: The upmost on your back Sir, you mistake me.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Sir, now I understand ye very well
but that you name my back,
Sure else my Cap had been the uppermost.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: farewell kind Lord, God send us merry meeting.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Amen my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: farewell dear friend, I hope your safe return.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord, and my most dear fellow in the Muses
farewell, farewell most noble Poet.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Adieu most honoured Lords.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: fair prison, welcome, yet me thinks,
for thy fair building, it is too foul a name.
Many a guilty soul, and many an innocent,
have breathed their farewell to thy hollow rooms.
I oft have entered into thee this way,
yet I thank God, never with a clearer conscience
than at this hour.
This is my comfort yet, how hard soever
my lodging prove, the cry of the poor suitor,
fatherless Orphan or distressed widow,
shall not disturb me in my quiet sleep.
on then in Gods name to our close abode:
God is as strong here as he is abroad

div0.stage: Enter Butler,Brewer, Porter, and horssekeper, seuerall wayes

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Robin Brewer, how now man? what cheer, what cheer?

sp.speaker: Brew.
sp.l: faith Ned Butler, sick of thy disease, and these our other fellows here Rafe Horssekeeper and Gyles Porter, sad, sad, they say my Lord goes to his trial today.

sp.speaker: Horss.
sp.l: to it man? why he is now at it, God send it him well to speed.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Amen, even as I wish to mine own soul, so speed it with my honourable Lord and Master Sir Thomas Moore.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I have nothing to do with matters above my capacity,
but as God judge me, if I might speak my mind, I think there lives not a more harmless Gentleman in the universal world.

sp.speaker: Brew.
sp.l: Nor a wiser, nor a merrier, nor an honester, go to, I will put that in upon mine own knowledge.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Nay, if ye bate him his due of his housekeeping, hang ye all, ye have many Lord Chancellors comes in debt at the years end, and for very house keeping?

sp.speaker: horsse.
sp.l: well, he was too good a Lord for us, and therefore I fear) God himself will take him: but I will be hanged if ever I have such another service.

sp.speaker: Brew.
sp.l: Soft man, we are not discharged yet, my Lord may come home again, and all will be well.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I much mistrust it, when they go to raining once, there is ever foul weather
sp.stage: Ent. Gough & Catesbie with a paper.
sp.l: for a great while after. But soft, here comes Master Gough and Master Catesbie, now we shall hear more.

sp.speaker: horss.
sp.l: Before God they are very sad, I doubt my Lord is condemned.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: God bless his soul, and a fig then for all worldly condemnation.

sp.speaker: Gough.
sp.l: well said Gyles Porter, I commend thee for it,
it was spoken like a well affected Servant,
of him that was a kind Lord to us all.

sp.speaker: Cate.
sp.l: which now no more he shall be, for dear fellows,
now we are masterless, though he may live,
so long as please the King: but law hath made him,
a dead man to the world, and given the Axe his head,
but his sweet soul to live among the Saints.

sp.speaker: Gough.
sp.l: Let us entreat ye, to go call together,
the rest of your sad fellows: by the Roll,
you are just seven score, and tell them what ye hear
a virtuous honourable Lord hath done,
even for the meanest follower that he had.
This writing found my Lady in his study
this instant morning, wherein is set down
each servant's name, according to his place,
and office in the house. on every man,
he frankly hath bestowen twenty Nobles
the best and worst together, all alike,
which Master Catesbie here forthwith will pay ye.

sp.speaker: Cate.
sp.l: Take it, as it is meant, a kind remembrance,
of a far kinder Lord, with whose sad fall,
he gives up house, and farewell to us all.
Thus the fair spreading Oak falls not alone,
but all the neighbour plants and under trees:
are crushed down with his weight. no more of this,
Come and receive your due, and after go,
Fellow-like hence, copartners of one woe.

div0.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Moore the Lieutenant,and a seruaunt attending as in his chamber in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Master Lieutenant, is the warrant come,
If it be so, in Gods name, let us see know it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: My Lord, it is.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: it is welcome Sir to me, with all my heart,
his blessed will be done.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Your wisdom Sir, hath been so well approved,
And your fair patience in imprisonment,
hath ever shown such constancy of mind,
and christian resolution in all troubles:
As warrants us, you are not unprepared.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: no Master Lieutenant, I thank my God,
I have peace of conscience, though the world and I,
are at a little odds: But we will be even now I hope,
ere long: when is the execution of your warrant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: so Sir, I thank ye,
I have not lived so ill, I fear to die.
Master Lieutenant, I have had a sore fit of the stone tonight,
But, the King hath sent me such a rare receipt
I thank him, as I shall not need to fear it much.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: in life and death, still merry Sir Thomas Moore.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Sirrah fellow, reach me the urinal,
ha, let me see, gravel in the water
The man were likely to live long enough
so pleased the King: here fellow, take it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Shall I go with it to the doctor Sir?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: no, save thy labour, we will cozen him of a fee,
Thou shalt see me take a dram tomorrow morning,
shall cure the stone I warrant, doubt it not.
Master Lieutenant, what news of my Lord of Rochester

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: yesterday morning was he put to death.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: The peace of soul sleep with him,
he was a learned and a reverend Prelate,
and a rich man believe me.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If he were rich, what is Sir Thomas Moore,
that all this while hath been Lord Chancellor?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Say ye so Master Lieutenant? what do you think,
a man that with my time had held my place:
might purchase?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Perhaps my Lord, two thousand pound a year.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Master Lieutenant, I protest to you,
I never had the means in all my life
to purchase one poor hundred pound a year.
I think I am the poorest Chancellor
that ever was in England, though I could wish,
for credit of the place, that my estate were better.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: it is very strange.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: It will be found as true.
I think Sir, that with most part of my coin,
I have purchased as strange commodities,
as ever you heard tell of in your life.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Commodities my Lord?
might I with out offence) enquire of them?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Crutches Master Lieutenant) and bare cloaks.
For halting Soldiers, and poor needy Scholars,
have had my gettings in the Chancery.
to think but what a cheat the crown shall have,
by my attainder. I pre thee, if thou beest a Gentleman,
get but a copy of my Inventory.
that part of Poet that was given me,
made me a very unthrift.
For this is the disease attends us all,
Poets were never thrifty, never shall.

div0.stage: Enter Lady Moore mourning, daughters, M ar Roper

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: o noble Moore.
My Lord, your wife, your son in law, and daughters.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: son Roper, welcome, welcome wife and Girls.
why do you weep? because I live at ease?
did you not see, when I was Chancellor,
I was so cloyed with suitors every hour,
I could not sleep, nor dine, nor sup in quiet.
here is none of this, here I can sit and talk,
with my honest Keeper half a day together
laugh and be merry, why then should you weep?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: These tears my Lord for this your long restraint
hope had dried up, with comfort that we yet,
although imprisoned, might have had your life.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: to live in prison, what a life were that?
The King I thank him) loves me more than so.
tomorrow I shall be at liberty,
to go even whither I can,
after I have dispatched my business.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ah husband, husband, yet submit yourself,
have care of your poor wife and children

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: wife, so I have, and I do leave you all,
to his protection, hath the power to keep
you, safer than I can,
the father of the widow and the Orphan.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The world my Lord) hath ever held you wise,
if it shall be no distaste unto your wisdom:
to yield to the opinion of the state.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I have deceived myself, I must acknowledge;
and as you say son Roper, to confess the same:
it will be no disparagement at all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: His Highness shall be certified thereof, immediately.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Nay hear me wife, first let me tell ye how,
I had thought to have had a Barber for my beard,
now I remember, that were labour lost,
the headsman now shall cut off head and all.

sp.speaker: Ro. wife.
sp.l: father, his Majesty upon your meek submission,
will yet they say) receive you to his grace:
in as great credit as you were before

sp.speaker: Moore
sp.l: has appointed me to do a little business.
If that were past, my Girl thou then shouldest see,
what I would say to him about that matter.
But I shall be so busy until then:
I shall not tend it.

sp.speaker: daugh.
sp.l: Ah my dear father.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: dear Lord and husband.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Be comforted good wife, to live and love my children,
for with thee leave I all my care of them.
son Roper, for my sake, that have loved thee well,
And for her virtues sake, cherish my child.
Girl, be not proud, but of thy husbands love,
ever retain thy virtuous modesty.
that modesty is such a comely garment,
as it is never out of fashion: sits as fair,
upon the meaner woman, as the Empress.
no stuff that gold can buy, is half so rich,
Nor ornament that so becomes a woman.
live all, and love together, and thereby,
you give your father a rich Obsequy.

sp.speaker: both daugh.
sp.l: your blessing dear father.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I must be gone, God bless you,
to talk with God, who now doth call.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A my dear husband,

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Sweet wife, good night, good night,
God send us all his everlasting light.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I think before this hour,
More heavy hearts never parted in the Tower.

div0.stage: Enter the Sheriffes of London and their Officers at one doore,the warders with their Halbards at an other.

sp.speaker: 1.Sher.
sp.l: Officers, what time of day is it?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Almost eight a clock

sp.speaker: 2.Sher.
sp.l: we must make then, lest we stay too long.

sp.speaker: 1.Ward.
sp.l: Good morrow Master Shreeues of London, Master Lieutenant,
wills ye repair to the limits of the Tower
there to receive your prisoner.

sp.speaker: 1.Sher.
sp.l: go back, and tell his worship, we are ready.

sp.speaker: 2.Sher.
sp.l: go bid the Officers make clear the way,
there may be passage for the prisoner.

div0.stage: Enter Lieutenant and his Guarde with Moore

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: yet God be thanked, here is a fair day toward,
to take our journey in: Master Lieutenant,
It were fair walking on the Tower leads.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And so it might have liked my Sovereign Lord,
I would to God you might have walked there still.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Sir, we are walking to a better place.
o Sir, your kind and loving tears,
are like sweet odours to embalm your friend.
thank your good Lady, since I was your guest,
She has made me a very wanton in good sooth.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: o I had hoped we should not yet have parted.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: But I must leave ye for a little while,
within an hour or two, you may look for me.
But there will be so many come to see me,
that I shall be so proud, I will not speak.
And sure my memory is grown so ill,
I fear I shall forget my head behind me.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: God and his blessed Angels be about ye,
here Master Shreeues, receive your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Moore
sp.l: Good morrow Master Shreeues of London to ye both,
I thank ye that ye will vouch safe to meet me,
I see by this you have not quite forgot,
that I was in times past as you are now:
a Sheriff of London.

sp.speaker: 1.Sher.
sp.l: Sir, then you know our duty doth require it.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I know it well Sir, else, I would have been glad,
you might have saved a labour at this time.
Ah Master Sheriff, you and I have been of old acquaintance,
you were a patient Auditor of mine,
when I read the divinity lecture at Saint Lauraunces

sp.speaker: 2.Sher.
sp.l: Sir Thomas Moore, I have heard you oft, as many other did,
to our great comfort.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Pray God you may so now, with all my heart.
And as I call to mind,
when I studied the law in Lincolnes Inn,
I was of Council with ye in a cause.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: I was about to say so good sir thomas

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: o, is this the place?
I promise ye it is a goodly Scaffold.
in sooth, I am come about a headless errand,
For I have not much to say, now I am here.
well, let us ascend in Gods name
in troth me thinks your stayre is somewhat weak,
I pre thee honest friend, lend me thy hand,
to help me up: As for my coming down,
let me alone, I will look to that myself.

div0.stage: As he is going vp the stayres,enters the Earles of Surrye & Shrewsburie

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lords of Surrey and of Shrewesburie, give me your hands yet before we ye see, though it pleaseth the King to raise me thus high, yet I am not proud for the higher I mount, the better I can see my friends about me. I am now far voyage, and this strange wooden horse must bear me thither: yet I perceive by your looks you like my bargain so ill, that there is not one of ye all dare
walking.

venture with me. Truly here is a most sweet Gallery, I like the air of it better than my Garden at Chelsey. by your patience good people, that have pressed thus into my bed chamber: if you will not trouble me, I will take a sound sleep here.

sp.speaker: Shrew.
sp.l: My Lord, it were good you should publish to the world,
your great offence unto his majesty.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: My Lord, I will bequeath this legacy to the hangman, and do it instantly. I confess

his majesty hath been ever good to me, and my offence to his highness, makes me of a state pleader, a stage player, though I am old, and have a bad voice) to act this last Scene of my tragedy. I will send him for my trespass) a reverend head, somewhat bald, for it is not requisite any head should stand covered to so high majesty. If that content him not, because I think my body will then do me small pleasure, let him but bury it, and take it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, hold conference with your soul,
you see my Lord, the time of life is short.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I see it my good Lord: I dispatched that business the last night, I come hither only
by the hangman.
to be let blood, my doctor here tells me it is good for the head ache.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: I beseech ye my Lord forgive me.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: forgive thee honest fellow? why?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: For your death my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore
sp.l: O, my death? I had rather it were in thy power to forgive me, for thou haste the sharpest action against me, the law my honest friend) lies in thy hands now.

here is thy fee, and my good fellow, let my suite be dispatched presently: for it is all one pain to die a lingering death, and to live in the continual mill of a law suite. But I can tell thee, my neck is so short, that if thou shouldest behead an hundred noble men like myself, thou wouldst never get credit by it. Therefore look ye Sir) do it handsomely, or of my word thou shalt never deal with me hereafter.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: I will take an order for that my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: One thing more, take heed thou cutest not off my beard: o, I forgot, execution past upon that last night, and the body of it lies buried in the Tower. Come, let us to the block.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: My Lord, I pray ye put off your doublet.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: no my good friend, I have a great cold already, and I would be loathe to take more, point me meet the block, for I was never here before

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: to the East side my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Then to the East,
we go to sigh, that over, to sleep in rest.
no eye salute my trunk with a sad tear,
our birth to heaven should be thus: void of fear.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Stay, is it not possible to make a scape from all this strong guard? it is
There is a thing within me, that will raise
and elevate my better part above sight
of these same weaker eyes. And Master Shreeues,
for all this troupe of steel that tends my death,
I shall break from you, and fly up to heaven,
let us seek the means for this.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: My Lord, I pray ye put off your doublet.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: speak not so coldly to me, I am hoarse already,
I would be loathe good fellow to take more,
Point me the block, I never was here before.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: to the East side my Lord.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Then to the East,
we go to sigh, that over, to sleep in rest.
here Moore forsakes all mirth, good reason why,
the fool of flesh must with her frail life die.
no eye salute my trunk with a sad tear,
our birth to heaven should be thus: void of fear.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: A very learned worthy Gentleman
Seals error with his blood. Come, we will to Court.
let us sadly hence to perfect unknown fates,
whilst he tends progress to the state of states.
